The\i  \i0 on-site emergency generator, complying with this section, shall be of sufficient capacity to allow normal starting and running of the motor(s) driving the fire pump(s) while supplying all other simultaneously operated loads. Optional standby loads shall be automatically shed when necessary to ensure the proper starting and operation of the fire pump. \par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\tx1080\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar Subsection 695.3(C) - Add a new subsection 695.3(C) to read as follows:\ulnone         \ul\par
\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj (C) Multiple Independent Sources. \b0 Two or more feeder sources routed separately to the building and independently operated may be permitted for compliance with this section, as approved by the commissioner, where the reliability of the sources can be demonstrated.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\b\par
\par
SECTION 695.4    \b0\par
Section 695.4  -  Revise to read as follows:\ulnone\tab\tab\tab\tab\par
\ul\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\b 695.4 Continuity of Power. \b0 Circuits that supply electric motor-driven fire pumps shall be supervised from inadvertent disconnection in accordance with (A) or (B) below.\par
\b\par
(A) General. \b0 Each\b  \b0 utility and generator supply circuit that supplies an electric motor-driven fire pump or limited service fire pump shall be supplied from a single dedicated service disconnecting means and associated overcurrent protective device installed between the power source and one of the following: \b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par
\b0 (1) A listed fire pump controller\par
(2) A listed fire pump power transfer switch\par
(3) A listed combination fire pump controller and power transfer switch\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\i Exception 1: The service conductors may directly connect the power source to either the listed fire pump controller or combination fire pump controller and power transfer switch where available short circuit current is less than the rating of the fire pump controller or combination fire pump controller and power transfer switch.\par
\par
Exception 2: Where a limited service fire pump is connected to an emergency generator in addition to the electric utility source, the disconnecting means for either source is not required to be a service disconnecting means.\par
\par
Exception 3: Where the building service disconnecting means consists of multiple utility sources over 600 volts arranged through transformers to supply a network secondary, a disconnecting means connected to the network complies with the requirements of this section. \par
\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\i0 (B) Disconnecting Means and Overcurrent Protection\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj (1) Utility Service. \b0 Fire pumps and limited service fire pumps shall have overcurrent protection selected as to allow the operation of the fire pump for as long as the fire pump remains capable of running, except where direct connection is made in accordance with 695.4(A)(3) \i Exception\i0  \i 1\i0 :\b\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\b0 (1) Fire Pump. Fire pump overcurrent protection shall be selected at between 300 percent and 600 percent of motor full load current. \par
\par
(2) Limited Service Fire Pump. Limited service fire pumps shall be protected by overcurrent devices selected at 150 percent of motor full load current. The next larger available device size may be used where selection results in a non-standard device size.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\par
(3) Disconnecting means shall be listed to accept the selected overcurrent device with no modification.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj (2)  Generator Supply. \b0  When required to be connected to an emergency generator, fire pumps and limited service fire pumps shall have overcurrent protection selected in accordance with the following, except where direct connection is made in accordance with 695.4(A)(3) \i Exception\i0  \i 1\i0 :\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\par
\b0 (1) Fire Pump. Fire pumps shall be protected by an over current device selected at not less than 150 percent and not more than 300 percent of motor full load current.  \par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\tx1980\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj (2) Limited Service Fire Pump. Limited service fire pumps shall be protected by an overcurrent device selected at 150 percent of motor full load current. The next larger available size may be used where selection results in a non-standard size.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\tx1980\par
(3) Disconnecting means shall be listed to accept the selected fuse or circuit breaker trip with no modification.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\par
(4) A tap ahead of the on-site emergency generator disconnecting means shall be required for the fire pumps.\par
\par
\i Exception: Where multiple generators operate in parallel, the fire pump tap may be made on the parallel distribution bus.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\b\i0\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj (3)  Disconnecting Means.\b0  The disconnecting means shall comply with the following:\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\b0 (1) Be identified as suitable for use as service equipment.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\tx1980\par
(2) Be lockable in the closed position. Locking provisions shall remain in place with or without an installed lock.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\par
(3) Not located within equipment that feeds loads other than the fire pump.\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj (4) Be located as remote as practicable from other service disconnecting means with a minimum separation of 305mm (12 in.).\par
\i\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj Exception: (1), (3), and (4) shall not apply to fire pumps and limited service fire pumps connected to emergency generators.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\i0\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\b (4)  Disconnect Marking\b0 . The disconnecting means shall be marked \ldblquote Fire Pump - Do Not Disconnect\rdblquote . The letters shall be at least 25mm (1 in.) in height, and they shall be visible without opening enclosure doors. Disconnecting means shall be red in color.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\b (5)   Controller Marking.\b0  A placard shall be placed adjacent to the fire pump \par
controller stating overcurrent setting at 300 percent of motor full load current, the location of the disconnecting means, and the location of the key (if the disconnecting means is locked).\par
\par
\b (6)  Supervision. \b0 The power continuity shall be supervised by one of the following:\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\b0\par
(1) Central station signals confirming power source availability and pump running where central station connection is provided as required by building occupancy or use.\par
\par
(2) Local signaling device, audible and visual, for power source availability and pump running which is activated at a continuously attended location where central station connection is not otherwise required.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par
\par
\b SECTION 695.5 \b0\par
Section 695.5  -  Revise to read as follows:\ulnone\tab\tab\tab         \ul\par
\par
\b 695.5 Accessory Equipment\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj (A)  Transformers. \b0 Where the service or system voltage is different from the utilization voltage of the fire pump motor, a transformer protected by disconnecting means and overcurrent devices shall be permitted to be installed between the system supply and the fire pump controller in accordance with the following.\b\par
\par
(1) Size. \b0 Transformers shall be rated at a minimum of 125 percent of the sum of the fire pump motor(s) and pressure maintenance pump(s) motor loads, and 100 percent of the remaining load supplied by the transformer.\b\par
\par
(2) Overcurrent Protection. \b0 Primary disconnecting means and overcurrent devices shall be selected in accordance with 695.4(B)(1). Secondary disconnecting means and overcurrent devices shall not be permitted.\par
\par
\b (3) Feeder Source. \b0 The feeders on the primary and secondary of the transformer shall be sized in accordance with the requirements of 695.6 adjusted for the primary and secondary voltage.\par
\par
\b (B)  Utility Meters. \b0 Metering of fire pumps shall be current transformer driven or bypass type such that meter removal will not interrupt service to the fire pump. Metering may be dedicated to the fire pump or coincident with other building power use.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\fi-720\li1440\qj\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj (C) Rectifiers. \b0 Rectifiers may be used to supply existing DC fire pump installation in accordance with the following\b .\b0\par
\b\par
(1)  Size. \b0 Where a rectifier supplies an existing DC electric fire pump, it shall be rated at a minimum of 125 percent of the fire pump full load current plus 100 percent of the full load current of all other equipment connected to the rectifier.\b\par
\i\par
\b0 Exception: If largest motor is other than the fire pump, rectifier shall be sized at 125 percent of the largest motor and 100 percent of all other equipment.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\b\i0\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj (2) Overcurrent Protection. \b0 The primary disconnecting means and overcurrent device shall be rated at 150 percent of the rectifier full load current.\b  \b0 The DC fire pump shall be supplied by a dedicated connection on the secondary of the rectifier. Disconnecting means and overcurrent devices shall not be permitted.\par
\b\par
(3) Feeder Source.\b0  The feeders on the primary and secondary of the rectifier shall be sized in accordance with the requirements of 695.6 adjusted for the primary and secondary voltage.\par
\par
\b (4) Other Loads. \b0 Rectifiers installed to supply existing DC fire pumps shall be permitted to supply other loads. Rectifier capacity shall be increased in accordance with 695.5(C)(1). Each DC supply shall include a disconnecting means and overcurrent device sized in accordance with applicable sections of the code.\ulnone    \ul\par
\b\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar SECTION 695.6 \b0\par
Section 695.6 - Revise to read as follows: \par
\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj 695.6 Power Wiring. \b0 Power circuits and wiring methods shall comply with the requirements in 695.6(A) through (E), and as permitted in 230.90(A), \i Exception\i0  \i 4\i0 ; 230.94, \i Exception\i0  \i 4\i0 ; 230.208; 240.4(A); 240.13 and 430.31\i .\i0\par
\b\par
(A)  Supply Conductors: \b0 Fire pump and limited service fire pump supply conductors shall be physically routed outside a building(s) and shall be installed as service entrance conductors.  Where supply conductors cannot be physically routed outside buildings, routing through buildings is permitted where installed in accordance with Section 230.6(1), (2), (4) or (5).\par
\par
\i Exception: The supply conductors located in the electrical service room and generator room where they originate and in the fire pump room shall not be required to have the minimum 2-hour fire separation or fire resistive rating.\ulnone   \ul\par
\i0\par
\b (B)  Circuit Conductors: \par
\par
(1)  Fire Pumps. \b0 Fire pump supply conductors, including emergency supply conductors where emergency power is provided, on the load side of the final disconnecting means and overcurrent device shall be kept entirely independent of all other wiring. They shall supply only loads that are directly associated with the fire pump system, and shall be protected to resist potential damage by fire, structural failure, or operational damage. They shall be permitted to be routed through a building(s) using one of the following methods:\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li1080\qj\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\b0 (1) Encased in a minimum of 50mm (2 in.) concrete using rigid metal conduit (steel RMC), intermediate metal conduit, electrical metallic tubing or schedule 80 non-metallic conduit.\ulnone            \ul\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li1980\qj\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj (2) Rigid metal conduit (steel RMC) within an enclosed construction dedicated to the fire pump circuit(s) having a minimum of a 2-hour fire resistance rating.\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\b0 (3) A listed electrical circuit protective system with a minimum 2-hour fire resistance rating. The installation shall comply with any restrictions provided in the listing of the electrical circuit protective system.\b\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\b0\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\i Exception: The supply conductors located in the electrical service room and generator room where they originate and in the fire pump room shall not be required to have the minimum 2-hour fire separation or fire resistive rating.\ulnone    \par
\ul\par
\b\i0 (2) Limited Service Fire Pumps. \b0 Limited service fire pump supply conductors shall be installed in rigid metal conduit (steel RMC) or intermediate metal conduit (steel IMC).\par
\i\par
Exception: Where there are multiple sources of supply with means of automatic transfer from one source to the other, electrical metallic tubing (EMT) shall also be permitted.\i0\par
\b\par
(C)  Conductor Size. \b0 Conductors supplying a fire pump or a limited service fire pump shall have a rating not less than 125 percent of the full load current of the pump motor selected at no greater than 75 degrees operating temperature of the conductor type used.\b\par
\par
(D) Overload Protection.\b0  See 695.5(C)(2) for overload protection requirements.\ulnone   \ul\par
\b\par
(E)  Pump Wiring. \b0 All wiring from the controllers to the pump motors shall be in rigid metal conduit (steel RMC) or have a minimum 1-hour fire separation or fire resistance rating. \b\par
\par
\b0\i Exception No. 1: Liquidtight flexible metal conduit (maximum of 915mm (36 in.)) is permitted for final connection to motor terminal housing.\par
\par
Exception No. 2: Intermediate metal conduit (steel IMC) and electrical metallic tubing (EMT) shall be permitted for limited service fire pumps.\b\i0\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par

\ul\fs24 760.33\b0  \b Fire Alarm Circuit and Equipment Grounding.\b0  Fire alarm circuits and equipment shall be grounded in accordance with Article 250 and shall comply with the following requirements:  \par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\fi720\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\b (A) Grounding Electrode Conductor.\b0  A grounding electrode conductor shall be sized and installed in accordance with Article 250, Table 250.66, using a minimum of 10 AWG, at the primary and secondary power source supplying the fire alarm system.  \par

\b (B)  Equipment Grounding Conductor.\b0  A separate green insulated equipment grounding conductor shall be sized and installed in accordance with Article 250, Table 250.122, using a minimum of 10AWG, where there are conduits supplying 120V to the fire command center, control unit or distributed control cabinets.\par
\par
\b (C)  Grounding Separately Derived Supply.\b0   A green insulated equipment grounding conductor shall be sized and installed in accordance with Article 250, Table 250.122, using a minimum of 10 AWG, in distributed cabinets where the 120V supply is not derived from the main fire alarm power supply.  In steel framed buildings, an additional connection to local steel shall be permitted.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\qj\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\b SECTION 760.41\par
\b0 Section 760.41-\b  \b0 Delete the section in its entirety and replace to read as follows:\par
\b  \par
760.41 Power Source Requirements.\b0  The power source for fire alarm circuits shall comply with the following:\ulnone                     \ul\par
\par
\b (A) Primary Power Source.\b0  All fire alarm circuits shall be provided with a primary power source.\f1\fs20  \f0\fs24 The primary power source shall be generated electric power not exceeding 277/480 volts, supplied by utility company power or isolated plant. The primary power supply to the fire alarm system shall comply with the following:\par
\par
\b (1)  Primary Power Supply for the Fire Alarm System.\b0     Primary power supply for the fire alarm system shall be connected to the primary power source ahead of all building service disconnecting means so that the building service disconnecting means can be opened without de-energizing the fire alarm supply. All utility metering of the fire alarm system, including disabling or removal of meters, shall maintain power continuity to the fire alarm system at all times.\par
\par
\b (2)  Limited Interior Fire Alarm Systems.\b0   Primary power supply for sub-systems or other limited interior fire alarm systems may be connected to the power supply through the protected area of such systems by means of a connection ahead of the disconnecting means for the power supply to the protected area.\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720 FPN: Sub-systems and limited interior fire alarm systems may also use the connected means defined in paragraph (1) where available.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par
\b (B) Secondary Power Source.\b0  Where an emergency power system is provided or required to be provided for emergency system loads, the fire alarm circuits shall be provided with a secondary power source.  Batteries shall not be a substitute for connection to a secondary power source.\b\f1  \b0\f0 The secondary power source shall comply with the requirements for emergency power systems and/or emergency generator that are used for emergency systems loads as articulated below:\par
\par
\b (1) Generally.\b0   Emergency power systems complying with Chapter 27 of the 2008 Building Code shall be permitted to serve as a secondary power source or\par
\par
\b (2) Existing Buildings.\b0   Emergency power systems and/or emergency generators in existing buildings in compliance with Title 27, chapter 1, subchapter 6, section 27-396.4 of the Administrative Code (also referred to as the 1968 Building Code) shall be permitted to serve as the secondary power source.\ulnone    \ul\par
\par
The secondary power supply shall be connected such that all other disconnecting means serving other building emergency loads can be opened without de-energizing the facility fire alarm secondary power supply.\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720 FPN: The use of a main disconnecting means on the output of the generator(s) is permitted where the disconnection of all other loads does not interrupt the facility fire alarm system secondary power supply.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par
\b (C) Battery.\b0  Regardless of whether a secondary power source is also provided, each fire alarm system and subsystem shall be equipped with a storage battery power supply sized to meet the operating power requirements of the system in accordance with (1), (2) or (3) below and shall automatically connect to and operate the fire alarm system upon failure of the primary or secondary power supply or sources. Batteries shall not be a substitute for connection to a secondary power source when a secondary power source is required pursuant to subsection (B) above.\par
\par
\b (1) With Voice Communications Capability.\b0   Supervisory operation for 24 hours followed by full load operation for 6 hours for systems with voice communications capability.\par
\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720 FPN: A 45 minute period of voice and alarm operation at the maximum connected load shall be considered equivalent to 6 hours of total system operation.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\par
\b (2)\b0  \b Without Voice Communications Capability.\b0   Supervisory operation for 24 hours followed by full load operation for 15 minutes for systems without voice communications capability.\par
\par
\b (3)  Sub-systems or Other Limited Interior Fire Alarm Systems.\b0      Supervisory operation for 24 hours followed by full load operation for 5 minutes for sub-systems or other limited interior fire alarm systems operating within a facility that reports to the overall facility fire alarm system.\par
\par
\b (D) Arrangement of Power Sources.\b0  One source of power shall be connected to the fire alarm system at all times. The primary and secondary power sources shall be arranged and controlled by automatic transfer switches dedicated to the fire alarm system such that the secondary source will be automatically connected to the fire alarm system should the primary power source fail. The following conditions shall be observed:\par
\par
(1) Intermediary devices between the fire alarm system power supply and the power source, other than fused disconnect switches, transformers and automatic transfer switches are prohibited. Such disconnect switches, transformers and automatic transfer switches shall supply only the fire alarm system and other systems specifically permitted by applicable New York City rules and regulations. \par
\par
(2) The primary and secondary power source shall each be provided with a means of disconnect from the fire alarm system. Each disconnect shall consist of a fused disconnect switch, locked in the ON position and the key shall be kept on premises and made accessible only to authorized personnel.  Such disconnect shall be painted red and permanently identified as a fire alarm circuit and labeled as to system/location served, with a means of interrupting the unfused grounded and all ungrounded conductors. \par
\par
(3) The fire alarm system fused disconnect switch on the transformer secondary side shall comply with the requirements of the primary and secondary power source fused disconnect switches pursuant to Article 240. \par
\par
(4)  For buildings served at up to 300 volts to ground, the service voltage shall be transformed to 208/120 volts and a fire alarm fuse disconnect provided within a circuit length of ten (10) feet, shall be connected at the transformer secondary on the 208/120 volt side.  Fused cutouts shall be provided where multiple circuits are required to support the fire alarm system and related auxiliaries mounted in a fused cutout panel suitable for the number of circuits needed.\par
\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\li720\qj\par
\par
